but in stating it in Conference he had mentioned no precise period, and they might understand the offer as being to limit the whole Treaty to two years— He said that in the written Note, he should not make the offer at-all— Mr Clay said that if we accepted it with the limitation of four years it would be saddled with the Canadian Article as drawn by them— Mr Gallatin and I both thought that Dr Adams’s adherence to the Canadian Article was a mere freak of his own, and that they would readily consent to omit the Article.— We parted at Mr: Gallatin’s door leaving him to make a draft of the Note, to be sent— As we were sitting down to dinner I received a Note from Mr Gallatin, with the draft upon which he and Mr Clay had agreed, asking me to look it over, and saying they would call upon me immediately after dinner to prepare and send it— They accordingly came, and we made out the Note; which Mr Clay wrote, and we all signed— Mr Gallatin took it with him to send to Mr Robinson, who lives near his lodgings— I made out a copy of this Note, which brought the Evening to near Midnight.

22. V.15. Shortly after rising this Morning I received a Note from Lord Castlereagh’s Office announcing the splendid and complete victory of the Duke of Wellington and Marshal Blucher, over the French Army commanded by Buonaparte in person, on Sunday last the 18th. In the course of the day, I received from the same Office, two copies of the Gazette Extraordinary, containing the Duke of Wellington’s dispatch of the 19th.— Mr Beasley called upon me and left with me a copy of his power of Attorney from the Merchants in Virginia, which he had shewn me yesterday— I had visits from Dr Bollmann, to whom I gave a Passport and who told me he should go for France on Saturday; and from Messrs: John and Henry White, Cruger and Buchanan; and Ingraham, who has just arrived from Plymouth.— He told me that the Neptune had sailed on Sunday Morning— That Messrs: Gallatin and Clay had first fixed upon the 14th: as the latest day for her to sail,—they had afterwards fixed upon the 25th. and Mr Crawford said he supposed when that came they would fix upon the 10th: of July.— That Mr Bayard who was extremely ill, had himself no hopes of his recovery, and said that he wished to go home to die among his friends and family.— But Captain Jones declined sailing without written orders, which Mr Bayard hesitated to give, as not being of the Administration party— Mr Crawford said that he would take the whole of that responsibility upon himself, and they both signed the order to Jones to sail— Ingraham said that Mr Gallatin and especially Mr Clay were much displeased and disappointed by it— I paid visits with Mrs. Adams to the Danish Minister Mr Bourke and his Lady—to Mr and Mrs Perkins, and to Mr. Mrs and Miss Copley— Mr and Mrs Perkins were not at home— The others we saw— I received a letter from Mr Harris at St: Petersburg, enclosing a notice from the General Post-Office here, that there is a ship-letter there for me— After dinner Mr Adams rode out with the Children— I took a walk in Hyde Park, and was overtaken by a shower of rain, which hastened me home.

23. V. Mr Beasley came and gave me the Papers respecting the claim that he made for the restoration of Anthony Shaddock, as a prisoner of War— The Answer he received was that the matter was in a train of legal investigation. I called upon Mr Gallatin and Mr Clay, and returned some of the papers received from them relating to the commercial Negotiation taking others in their stead— On Dr: Bollman at his lodgings in Buckingham Street-Strand. He shewed me the medals which he had struck at the Monnoie des Medailles at Paris on Platina. They are those upon the Emperors of Russia and Austria and the king of Prussia’s visiting the Mint last year, and one of Napoleon with the Column of the Place Vendome; and that on the return of Louis 18 from England— He had sent one to Russia and told me that he gave 280 franks for striking the six. In the first instance they declined striking them at all from an apprehension that the hardness of the metal would break the dies— He had however shewn them a mode of doing it upon which they consented to try the experiment and succeeded— The proportional specific gravity of silver, gold and platina is 11. 19. and 21. and the proportional value at present of Platina is intermediate between silver and gold, about 4 to 1. to silver and 1/4 to 1 to Gold. Dr Bollman has a plan for making a coinage of Platina for which its infusibility and its gravity render it peculiarly convenient— The first preventing its being melted down, and the second making counterfeits of it impracticable. The Doctor had a few pieces with the Austrian Ducat stamp, which
he had got struck at Vienna— He also shewed me some of the metal in its natural state, something like gold-dust— The secret is to compound it into masses— And although it is one of the rarest substances in Nature, hitherto the uses to which it has been made applicable have not sufficed for the consumption of all the metal that has been found.— The Doctor thinks also that silver must continue to depretiate as it has already much depretiated in its value— The mines in Peru have for some years ceased working for want of a supply of quicksilver— But there is now a contact for that supply from the mines near Trieste, and the transportation has been undertaken by the house of Baring here—the Government having furnished a ship of war for the purpose— Dr Bollmann obtained a Passport yesterday from the alien office to go to France— Mr Ogden, and Mr William Bayard however came to me in the course of the day requesting a Letter from me to Mr Becket, the Under Secretary of State at the Alien Office, asking Passports for them to go to France. I doubted the propriety of this measure, though it was stated to me by Mr Bayard and Mr Joy to have been heretofore practiced by Mr King and Mr Monroe— I stopped at Mr Kinnaird’s house in Clarges Street, but did not find him at home.— At the London Coffee House, and left cards for Messrs: J. and H. White, Buchanan and Cruger— At the General Post Office in Lombard Street, where I took up the ship Letter of which I received the notice, yesterday from St: Petersburg.— At the Counting House of Messrs: Baring, where I saw Mr Alexander Baring and had some Conversation with him respecting the loan proposed by the Instructions which I have received from the Secretary of the Treasury; I stated to him the terms to which I was limited, and found there was nothing to be done upon them— He said the United States six per Cents were now at 90 and 91. The Louisiana Stock about 95. but even so small a sum as three Millions of Dollars brought into the market would reduce them lower— I went to Mr Williams’s in Finsbury Square— He is gone with Mr and Mrs Gore to the Isle of Wight— I had taken with me the Articles which I procured for my father; to get them sent on board the Galen, but was obliged to take them home with me again. I returned the visits of Mr Nevett and Mr Ingraham, neither of whom was at home.— It was near five when I reached my lodgings again. Mr George Joy came in shortly after, and dined with us.— He renewed his proposition of going without authority to negotiate for american claims of indemnity at the Court of Louis 18. Upon which I answered him as before.— He recommended to me to send the Articles for my father to the New-England Coffee-House to Captain Tracy, Master of the Galen; and wrote a line to him requesting him to take them— In the Evening we all rode round the Streets to see the illuminations for the Great Victory of the 18th.— They were not general, nor very magnificent— The whole range of their Variety was “Wellington and Blucher—Victory G.P.R. and G.R.”— The transparencies were very few, and very bad We came home about Midnight.

24. VII. Sent the parcels for my father to Captain Tracey at the New-England Coffee-House, with a Note requesting him to take charge of them; and received from him an answer promising that he would. Wrote a Letter to Mr Erving.— Received Notice that the Prince Regent, will hold a Levee next Thursday, and the man who brought it, told me there would be on Monday a notice for a Court mourning. Mr Everett came with Mr Perkins’s son Stephen, to ask for Passports to go to Holland and Germany. They are to go next Wednesday and I promised to give Mr Everett some Letters as he had requested—with the exception of one for Madame de Stael, which I declined giving, as not being upon a sufficient footing of familiarity with her to take the Liberty. But as Mr Everett is going to spend a year or two at Gottingen, and intends after that to go to Paris, I told him that if I should then be at Paris, in Europe, and Madame de Stael at Paris, I would endeavour to obtain an introduction for him to her. He told me that his brother who was appointed to go as Secretary of Legation with Dr Eustis to Holland, had written him that he did not expect to sail this Summer, and he expressed the wish that his brother might be appointed as the Secretary to this Legation. I promised to write to the Government, renewing the request— I had visits from the Comte de la Chastre the French Ambassador, from the Chevalier de Freire, the Portuguese Minister; from the Duke de Sorentino, Mr and Miss Haven, who are going to Scotland, and the two Mr Atkinson’s.— I called upon Mr Hubbard, who goes out in the Galen, and left at his lodgings a Letter to my father with the seal, which I have had engraved for him— Received from the British Plenipotentiaries, an Answer to our last Note, which I took to Mr Clay & Mr Gallatin, we met again at Mr Gallatin’s at 5 O’Clock, and wrote and signed a reply to the British Note, to be sent this Evening. I met Sir John Coghill at Mr Gallatin’s.— After dinner I walked with George to Dr Bollman’s lodgings, where, not finding him at home, I left two packets for Mr Jackson our Chargé d’Affaires at Paris, one, that I made up this morning, and the other that which I had given to Mr Rapin.— He went to New-Haven, near Brighton; found the communication so entirely stopp’d that he could not procure a passage to France—upon which he returned to France, and brought back my Letters.— We then went down to Westminster Hall, and returned home by the way of Pall Mall, St. James’s Street, and Bond and Oxford Streets where we viewed all the illuminations, of the second Night— They were the same as last Evening— I have at length finished one Letter to the Secretary of State; but I am yet far from having brought my course of occupations into systematic order.

25. VI:30. From Breakfast time until half-past four O’Clock we had a continual succession of visitors— Mr S. G. Perkins came for a Passport for himself, his wife and Son, to go to Holland— A sudden determination which he has taken, upon the arrival of a vessel from Boston, yesterday. I had some conversation with him upon the subject of our commerce with the East and West Indies— He thinks the East India Company, will always favour our trade with their settlements, but he apprehends the influence of individuals, and wishes on that account that it could be secured by Treaty.— Mr Sheaffe also called upon me, with a Mr Appleton lately arrived from America. Mr Clagett, an old acquaintance of Mr Johnson and his family came and invited us all to dine with him at Clapham Rise where he now resides—for next Sunday— Mr Rotch originally of Nantucket, and whose family still resides at New Bedford, Massachusetts. He has himself at one time been settled at Dunkirk, and for the last twelve or fifteen years in this Country. He says his intention now is to return soon to America. We had also a visit from Mr and Madam Bourke— Mrs Adams and the Children rode in the Park, where I took an hour’s walk— After dinner we all walked in the Regent’s Park— After we returned, Mr Todd called to ask for a Passport. He proposes going to-morrow Evening or Tuesday Morning for Liverpool there to embark for the United States.

26. VII:15. The first news of this Morning, contained in the Morning Chronicle, is the abdication of the Emperor Napoleon, upon the loss of the battle on the 18th:— From Breakfast time again, I had not the disposal of one moment of the day— Mr Mallison, a person who has an invention for saving the lives of Shipwrecked Mariners came first— He sent me three weeks since, a pamphlet upon the subject, which I have not had yet time to read. He has an application before Parliament relating to it, and expects it will be taken up in the House of Commons to-morrow— He relies upon the assistance of Mr Whitbread and Sir F. Burdett— Admiral Tchitchagoff called upon me—and requested me to send to some of my friends in America, copies of his pamphlets upon the passage of the Beresina— Captain Johnson a half pay British naval Officer, and heretofore one of Mr Fulton’s Associates, came with a proposal to blow up the whole Algerine fleet by submarine explosion. He says that Fulton was the greatest Genius in the universe— That he is himself the depository of all Mr Fulton’s plans, and has improved upon that for submarine explosion, so as to have brought it to a perfect certainty. He offers at his own expense and risque, without putting the United States to a dollar of previous cost, to blow up every Algerine ship of War, upon the water; if the United States will pay him half the value of all those that he shall destroy.— Sometimes I thought the man crazy—but on the whole I believe he is only a projector— He said he would send me his proposals in writing, and complained that both Mr Fulton, and himself had been very ill used by this Government. I received from the Portuguese Minister a Packet addressed to Mr Crawford, by the hand-writing, apparently from Mr Sumter at Rio Janeiro; forwarded from the Chevalier de Brito at Baden.— I called to see Mr De Freire, who was not at home— I went also to make enquiries of the character of a man who offers himself as a footman. The custom here is to give no written certificates; but all the characters of Servants are given upon verbal enquiries.— The Gentleman with whom this man lived is out of town, and I was obliged to take the character, from his Butler— I went over to the Borough to see Mr Grubb, and enquire if I could give him some employment.— He was not at home, and I left a request that he would call on me to-morrow Morning.— Returning home, I paid a visit to Mr and Mrs Bayard in Holles Street, but did not see them. I found at my door a Mr Barry an Englishman just arrived from France; who brought me a Letter from Mr Erving; and one for the Duke of Sorentino— He was with another Gentleman who introduced him, but who was himself a stranger to me— Mr Barry confirms the accounts of Napoleon’s abdication, and the transactions at Paris. I received from the Lord Chamberlain’s Office, notice of a Court Mourning, and (from the British Plenipotentiaries a Note to inform us that they must refer our last proposals to their Government.) I took it to Messrs: Clay and Gallatin, to whom I proposed to present them to the Prince Regent at the Levee, next Thursday. Mr Clay answered hesitatingly—and said he had thoughts of proposing to Mr Gallatin to go away, without waiting any longer for the negotiation— Mr Gallatin said he would see Mr Goulburn to-morrow to enquire, whether they intended to delay their further answer, and strongly disinclined to be presented at the Levee. They are definitively to send me their answer, to-morrow Morning— Mr Beasley had called early this morning, and told me that Mr Charles King had arrived in town, from Lisbon. While I was out Mr King came and paid a visit— A Mr Simon had also called with a note from Mr Gallatin. He wanted a Passport for a friend of his a Mr Berier, and his family— He is a Frenchman by birth, but a Citizen of the United States— He came from France in March, and is now returning there. We all went this Evening to Covent-Garden Theatre, and saw Romeo and Juliet, with Milton’s Comus. The part of Juliet was performed by Miss O’Neill, now the most fashionable actress on the Stage— She has real merit, and may become an admirable performer; but is not yet to be compared with Mrs Siddons or Mrs Jordan. Comus was made a much more splendid exhibition than I had ever seen it— The house was full— Home about midnight.

27. VI:30. Mr Grubb called upon me this morning, and I gave him some papers to be copied as soon as possible— I also agreed with him on the terms upon which I should employ him—at present at £4. Sterling per week, and hereafter, if I engage him, at 150 Guineas a year. I enquired of Mr Beasley what he gives for Clerks, and find it to be from 150 to 200 Guineas— I had four applications for Passports— From Mr Simon for that of Mr Berier and his family— From Mr Haven for one for himself and his Sister, who have concluded to go to Holland with Mr and Mrs Perkins, instead of going to Scotland— From a Mr Steel of Pennsylvania, and from Mr Bange, born a Hollander, but a naturalized Citizen of the United States— Mr Ogden also came to say that he could not obtain at the alien-office a Passport to go to France, without a Letter from me to Lord Sidmouth requesting it— I wrote a Note to Lord Castlereagh requesting to see him; with the intention of speaking to him on this matter, and on that of Shaddock— I called upon the Danish Minister to enquire as to the usages in regard to the Court Mournings, when Uniforms are worn. He said nothing was necessary but a crape round the left arm. I asked also about the enquiries of condolence at the Prince Regent’s on the occasion of the Death of the Duke of Brunswick— He said he had made none, and did not think it necessary that any should be made. The Newspapers say that they have been numerous the last three days— I returned the visit of Mr Temple Franklin, but was not received— Mr Grubb had told me he was unwell— I visited also Coll: Trumbull, and Mr Charles King. Coll: Trumbull is to sail for New-York, about the 15th. of next Month— Mr King was overset from the Mail Coach in coming from Falmouth, and had his shoulder dislocated— He has his arm now in a sling. He has a Letter from Lisbon of the 16th. mentioning the arrival of our Squadron on the Coast there, and the return of the Algerines into the Mediterranean. They had seventeen prizes, but he had heard of no Americans being among them.— I visited Mr Renwick at Brunet’s Hotel, but did not see him— He had called some days since, and left a Letter of Introduction, from my nephew John A. Smith. When I came home I made up a dispatch for the Secretary of State, and a packet of Newspapers, which Mrs Adams after dinner took down to the New-England Coffee-house to be delivered to Captain Tracey of the Galen. I walked about an hour, and on returning home, found several Letters, and a packet of Newspapers from Mr Jackson at Paris; brought by Lieutenant Newcomb— Mr Jackson confirms the abdication of Napoleon, and the desperate situation of France.

28. VI:15. For the first time since my arrival in London, I have retrieved the arrears of this Journal; which commenced on the day when we sailed from Havre, and from the beginning of this month had run up to twelve days— I had this day two applications from foreigners for Passports to go to America— They said they were sent to me from the Alien Office— Received a Note from Lord Castlereagh appointing half past eleven O’Clock to-morrow morning to see me.— A person who called himself a brother of the Mayor of Cork came to make enquiries concerning the purchase and inheritance of real Estate by aliens in America. He knew not in what State, but it was in the neighbourhood of Philadelphia— Mrs Perkins, and Mr and Miss Haven came and took leave—going to Holland— I wrote three Letters of Introduction for Mr Everett— Count Ginnasi, whom I had seen at Ghent came and paid me a visit— He has a second engraving of his antient ring— We dined at four O’Clock, and after dinner I went with George to the House of Commons— We were admitted under the Gallery— The debate was upon a grant of £6000 Sterling annually in addition to £18000 the present Establishment of the Duke of Cumberland, on the occasion of his marriage with the Princess of Solms— The house was unusually full, and the debate animated, though temperate— The speakers in favour of the grant, were Lord Castlereagh, Mr Vansittart the Chancellor of the Exchequer, and Mr Bathurst—those against it, were Mr Keene, Sir M. W. Ridley, Mr Bennet, Sir C. Burrell, and Mr Wynne— The characters of both parties to the marriage, were treated with very little respect on one side of the house. The debate was of about an hour, when the Committee of the whole divided, upon which occasion all strangers are obliged to withdraw. The vote was 87 for and 70 against the grant— We afterwards returned into the house, when they were considering the vote of Credit of six Millions— Mr Whitbread said a few words to express the hope that no part of it would be given to Spain; and Mr Wynne to say that whatever might ultimately be the Government of France, such security would be taken of it as would prevent her from disturbing the Peace of Europe hereafter— Three fourths of the members who had attended on the question of the grant to the Duke of Cumberland, left the house immediately after that question was taken.— Mr Mallison’s Invention was disposed of before we reached the house— We came away shortly before the adjournment, and walked home through the two Parks— Mr Gallatin had been here to enquire if I had received the note from the British Plenipotentiaries— Mr Todd called late in the Evening; and is going soon for Liverpool. Lieutenant Newcomb also paid me a visit this Morning— He left Paris on the 24th.— The Condition of France is unexpressibly wretched. It was with the utmost difficulty that Mr Newcomb obtained permission to come over— He left Count Otto, at Boulogne; sent for the purpose of negotiating with this Country. But Otto himself has been denied the permission to come to London.

29. VI:30. Wrote a Letter to the Secretary of the Treasury on the subject of the proposed loan. At half past eleven O’Clock, I went to Lord Castlereagh’s according to appointment— I found in his Antichamber the Russian Ambassador Count Lieven, the Marquis of Camden— Mr Planta, and one or two other persons— After waiting a few minutes I was received in his Lordship’s Cabinet.— I gave him Mr Maury’s Commission as Consul at Liverpool, which he had sent me, to obtain the exequatur— Lord Castlereagh said it would be immediately made out.— I then spoke to him of the
case of Anthony Shaddock, a man taken the last Autumn as Master of a coasting vessel between Savannah and Amelia Island. A Citizen of the United States— Taken as a prisoner of War— Paroled at Bermuda for some time as a prisoner of War, and then sent over here in the Vengeur—to be tried by a Court Martial as one of the mutineers of the Hermoine frigate— I said that it was impossible for me to wish to screen from condign punishment a person who should have been guilty of such a crime as that—but the man was a Citizen of the United States.— I had reason to believe that the Evidence upon which the suspicion against him had been raised was very weak— He declared that he knew nothing of that crime— I hoped and trusted he was innocent— But the principle to the benefit of which I thought him entitled was the fulfilment of the Treaty stipulation to restore All Prisoners of War— Lord Castlereagh did not at first recollect the affair of the Hermoine frigate; but afterwards said he had some remembrance of it, and thought it a very disgusting thing. He enquired where the man now was— I did not know, but he had been sent to England I said in the Vengeur— He said it seemed to him it brought back again the question of the War— That they did not consider a British Subject as a Prisoner of War— That every Government in Europe would consider such persons as Traitors, and not as Prisoners of War— I said I was not acquainted with any such usage in Europe— That it was true the case of AEneas M’Donald in this Country appeared to sanction the principle in its rigour— He had indeed been sentenced, but not executed— But this man was not triable as a traitor; even on that principle— He had not been taken in arms, but in a merchant vessel. While the War had lasted, Great-Britain might adhere with what strictness she thought proper to the principle for which she contended in theory, but having stipulated in the Treaty for the restoration of all Prisoners of War, I conceived that it was no longer competent for her to make any discrimination, or to enquire where any individual prisoner was born— I said I had preferred asking this interview, and stating the case verbally, to the formality of an official note with a hope that the man might be released without such public interposition— Lord Castlereagh expressed himself perfectly satisfied as to the manner of my application; but he gave me no reason to expect that it would be effectual— He said he supposed that the Admiralty Court was that where the trial was to take place— I said I had supposed so, when the case was first represented to me; but I afterwards learnt that the trial was to be by a Court Martial— This Circumstance had strongly confirmed me in the impression that it was my duty to claim in the man’s behalf the benefit of the Treaty— The Agent for Prisoners of War, had in the first instance claimed the release of the man, and had been answered that the matter was in a train of legal investigation— But the mode of trial itself, was one not congenial to the general feelings either of Englishmen or of Americans, nor such as in their opinions could give the fullest Confidence to Innocence— First to be sent across the Atlantic Ocean, and then to be tried by a merely military tribunal were hardships, from which I felt it my duty to use every endeavour to redeem any American Citizen— The fulfilment of the Treaty it was equally my duty to require— This man had some property in America; and had friends who took an interest in his situation here— They had applied to me for my interposition in his behalf, which I could not feel myself justified in denying. Lord Castlereagh took a minute of the man’s name and of the Ship in which he was sent to England, as if to make further enquiry into the matter; but without promising any thing.— I then spoke of the Passports— I told him that until within these five or six days, Passports to go to France had been delivered at the Alien Office, to Americans desirous of going there, upon their producing Passports given them by me— That several of them had now been told that something further from me would be necessary— Several foreigners had also been to me stating the wish to go to America, and that they were also referred from the Alien Office to me— It was my desire to conform myself to the regulations of this Government, and at the same time to secure to my fellow-citizens the liberty of going where their concerns may call them— He said he did not know precisely what the regulations were— The Alien-Office was in the Home Department under Lord Sidmouth; we should see him at the Levee; and it would perhaps be best to speak on the subject to him— I mentioned again the misconstruction of an Article in the Treaty of Ghent, by the British naval Commander in Chesapeake Bay, relating to the restoration of captured Slaves, and asked him if he had not received some communication upon the subject from America— He said there was a voluminous Correspondence concerning it received yesterday from Mr Baker— He had apparently not read it, and said that he should be obliged to leave town to-morrow Evening for Bruxelles— But during his absence the business of his Department would be transacted by Lord Liverpool and Lord Bathurst— He asked if this matter concerning the slaves was not the same about which Mr Horner had yesterday made a Motion in the House of Commons— I said I believed not— From what I had seen in the Newspapers of Mr Horner’s motion, it referred to Slaves said to have been taken in the United States, and sold in the West-Indies— What I now referred to was the restoration of Slaves, taken during the War, stipulated to be restored, but still detained by the British Naval Commanders. He said it should be attended to, and asked if I had any particular desire that Mr Bagot’s departure should be hastened— I said I could only
desire that he might go as soon as would suit his own convenience and that of his Government— I returned home and at 2 O’Clock went and attended the Prince Regent’s Levee— All the foreign Ambassadors and Ministers were there; and I was introduced by Mr Rayneval to the Comte de la Chatre the Ambassador of Louis 18. I also became acquainted with the Spanish Ambassador and the Sardinian and Turkish Ministers, and renewed old acquaintances with Baron Rehausen, the Swedish Minister, whom I had known at the Hague, and with Mr Curtoys, Secretary of the Spanish Embassy, whom I had known in the like capacity at Berlin— The Turkish Chargé d’Affaires, Mr Ramadani told me that he had been formerly acquainted here with Mr Russell— He spoke of our war with the Algerines, and expressed a wish that the United States would send a Minister to Constantinople.— He told me that the Algerine Squadron lately off Lisbon had taken a vessel under the Ottoman flag, which had sailed from this place with his papers— But he had no doubt she would be restored when she got into Port— The Sardinian Minister said they were doing infinite mischief to the Navigation of his Country, and that our Squadron would meet with every assistance and good Office that could be afforded them in the Island of Sardinia— I spoke to Lord Sidmouth on the subject of the Passports at the Alien Office— He requested me to call on Saturday next at 12 O’Clock, at his Office—the Home Department, when he said he would introduce to me Mr Becket, whom he had placed at the head of the Alien-Office, and who would immediately settle with me some general rule, by which American Citizens, desirous of going to France may be accommodated— He assured me that every disposition to accommodate American Citizens would be shewn that was possible— The first, or Diplomatic Levee was short—the Duke of Cumberland was the only Prince of the blood present. The Regent spoke a few words to all the Ambassadors and Ministers, and asked me if I had ever been in England before. When the second Levee commenced there was a crowd of persons thronged into the chamber, among whom I knew only Mr Bailey, the Consul at St Petersburg— He came up to me, and asked me if it was over— He said that he had been presented and knighted, but that it was done so in an instant that he hardly knew how it happened—never having been there before. I congratulated him upon his new dignity— He said it was about as good as the order of St Wolodimir— As we retired I spoke to Baron Fagel, the Dutch Ambassador, and enquired after his brother Robert, and his brother in Law Boreal— He told me that Boreal had escaped unhurt in the late Battle, though his Regiment had been almost destroyed— I came home from the Levee about four O’Clock, and just before dinner received a Note from the British Plenipotentiaries agreeing to sign a Convention, as we proposed by our Note of the 24th. and proposing to meet us at the Board of Trade at 2 O’Clock to-morrow. I took it immediately after dinner to Mr Clay— He sent over for Mr Gallatin, who came, and they both read the British Note— There was some question, whether it required a reply— I thought and strongly urged that it did— We agreed to meet at one O’Clock to-morrow at my lodgings. I walked afterwards to the Park, to meet Mrs Adams and the Children, but they were returning home. I met Mr Todd, who was going to take his seat in a Stage for Liverpool, to go to-morrow Morning.

30. VI:30. Lieutenant Newcomb came this morning and took his Passport and that of Mr Remsen to go to Bristol or Liverpool and to the United States— I gave him a Letter for the Secretary of the Treasury and a Packet of Newspapers for the Secretary of State— Between one and two O’Clock, Messrs Clay and Gallatin came to my lodgings, to consult with me, upon the Note which we received last Evening from the British Plenipotentiaries. Mr Clay thought no reply from us was necessary— I thought one indispensable— Of two alternatives which we offered them in our last Note, they accept one; but with pretensions of generosity, as if they were granting a favour, which I thought it essential to repel— I insisted on this, until Mr Gallatin took from his Pocket the draft of a Note which he had prepared and with the substance of which I was satisfied— Mr Clay ultimately consented to sign it, and immediately transcribed it from the draft.— We took it with us, and delivered it ourselves to the British Plenipotentiaries. We were now agreed upon the substance of the Convention which is to be for four years from the signature and consists of five Articles.— From the Drafts made of the second Article on both sides its ultimate form was agreed upon— Mr Gallatin had inserted the exception relative to the West-Indies, in the body of the Article— Mr Robinson had proposed to make a separate Article of it. The conclusion was to put it in a paragraph at the Close of the Article— There was in the East-Indian Article a proviso that American Vessels might touch for refreshment, but not for Commerce at the Cape of Good-Hope, the Island of St. Helena, or other British places in the African or Indian Seas, in their voyages to or from the British Possessions in India. Mr Gallatin observed to the British Plenipotentiaries, that this did not allow the same privileges to American Vessels going to or from China. The limitation was a novelty— It had not been in the former Treaties, and he mentioned it now, not that we intended to make a point of it, but for the British Plenipotentiaries to consider whether it was worth adhering to—particularly as it would not prevent a single American voyage to China. It then became proper to consider of the preamble— Mr Goulburn drew one up, from former Precedents, which he shewed to Mr Gallatin. He said that in the Preamble to the Treaty of Ghent, there had been a mistake— Mr Clay asked him what it was— Goulburn avoided answering the Question; but said that one of the Clerks in the foreign Office, upon his return here had told him they had made a mistake— It did not
however affect the validity of the Treaty. I observed then that there had been another error, both in the Preamble, and in the order of the signatures at Ghent, which it would be necessary to avoid repeating at present. The first was that in the Copies on both sides the king of Great-Britain, and the British Plenipotentiaries were first named, and the second was that the signatures all followed each other in succession,—the American Plenipotentiaries signing under those of Great-Britain. The usage of all Treaties between European Sovereigns we understood to be what is called the alternative—each of the parties and his Plenipotentiaries being first named, in the copy which he receives— The Signatures of the respective Plenipotentiaries being on a line, and alternate. Those of each party signing first, in the Copy which he receives— With regard to the order of the signatures, the British Plenipotentiaries made no positive objection; but Dr Adams said he did not know there was any such usage, and Mr Goulburn said the same.— I told Goulburn that if he would take the trouble of enquiring at the foreign Office, he would find it an universal usage— As to the alternative, in the preamble, and in naming the Parties in the Treaty, Dr Adams said that in such a case the Copies would not be alike— I said that as it was a practice by common consent generally established and understood, and the mere variation of order in naming the Parties made no change either in the substance or in the words of the Treaty, it did not in any manner affect the essential accuracy of the copies. Mr Goulburn said that in this case, the changes must then run through the whole Treaty— I said if the Preamble and ratifying clause were right, it was not so material in the body of the Treaty; but if he would have a draft copy made out as was agreed, and as they intended to execute their copy, and send it to me, I would have our Copy made out, corresponding to it, and ready to be executed Monday Morning. They promised to send me such a draft Copy— Mr Clay and Mr Gallatin had expressed some wish to finish the business this day or to-morrow. But Mr Robinson and Mr Goulburn were under the necessity of attending at 4 O’Clock the House of Commons, where there was to be a close vote upon a question of a grant of £6000 per annum to the Duke of Cumberland on his Marriage; and Mr Goulburn was obliged to go out of town to-morrow, and will not return till Monday Morning.— Mr Gallatin said he did not know how the usage was, with regard to the alternatives in the Treaty; but he knew the order in which we had signed and sealed at Ghent had been wrong— That it ought to have been in parallel lines— Mr Robinson finally said he believed we were right— At least he knew it had been so at the Treaty of Chaumont, which was the only Treaty that he had ever been before concerned in making.— We left the British Plenipotentiaries just at four— I took over to Mr Grubb, my Letter Book of the Joint Negotiations, and a number of Papers to be copied into it— Thence I went to the Guildhall Coffee-House, to see Mr Chevalier— Mr Beasley had informed me by a Note, that Mr Chevalier would go to-morrow morning for France— He was not at his lodgings: I left with my Card, a letter for Mr Erving, from the Duke of Sorentino, which he had brought to me yesterday— I returned home to dinner, and wrote to my Mother. After dinner, I took a ride with Mrs Adams to Hyde Park corner, and we walked from thence to Kensington Garden, and the Turnpike at the lower end of it.— I was apprehensive this morning that Lord Castlereagh in the hurry and pressure of business, would forget the application which I made to him yesterday, in behalf of Anthony Shaddock, and I sent him a note to remind him of it— Lord Castlereagh left town, for Bruxelles this Evening.

Day. The month has elapsed in a state of confusion resembling that of the first week after my arrival here— My Correspondence runs in arrears constantly accumulating. This Journal has also a perpetual tendency to run in arrear.— The essential difficulty of all Journalizing is that the more the day is absorbed by occupation, the less time is left for committing the record of it to writing. We have settled none of our family arrangements— The Children are still all with us, it being now the midsummer Vacation at all the schools— They have masters for writing and arithmetic, fencing and dancing.— But their time is not fully employed, and mine is so completely taken up, that I have none left to attend to them— The Conferences with the British Plenipotentiaries, and with my own Colleagues, upon the Convention which we have now agreed to sign, has consumed a large portion of the month, and the minutes of them in this Journal, have proportionally swollen its narrative— Visits, dinners, Passports, and Projectors, have left me scarcely a moment for preparing my own public dispatches, or answering the Letters of my private Correspondents.— I rise irregularly from five to half past seven, and after the reading which I begin the day with, write in this Journal until ten— We then breakfast, and I have visitors or applicants for Passports, often without intermission, until four in the afternoon. My own means of escaping is to go out myself, which I have frequently been obliged to do, for business, and often to return visits— From four to six, I have occasionally two hours during which I can write, and when possible employ them in that manner— From Six to Seven we dine, and after dinner, I sometimes ride out with the rest of the family, but more commonly walk an hour or two, for exercise—alone or with my Son, George. We return home between nine and ten, soon after which, I finish the day.
